---
title: 'How to allow SAR collapse across local and continental scales: a resolution
  of the controversy between Storch et al. (2012) and Lazarina et al. (2013)'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-WTLGFLT5" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Šizling, A. L., Šizlingová, E., Tjørve, E., Tjørve, K. M. C., &#38; Kunin, W. E. (2017). How to allow SAR collapse across local and continental scales: a resolution of the controversy between Storch et al. (2012) and Lazarina et al. (2013). <i>Ecography</i>, <i>40</i>(8), 971–981. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1111/ecog.02181">https://doi.org/10.1111/ecog.02181</a></div> </div>

</article>
<div id="csl-bib-meta-WTLGFLT5" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-WTLGFLT5" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Šizling et al. undersøkte korleis ein kan føreseie artsrikdom (talet på ulike artar) frå lokale område til større, kontinentale skalaer. Dette er viktig fordi forståing av desse mønstera kan hjelpe økologar med å forvalte habitat og verne biodiversitet, særleg på stader der direkte observasjon er vanskeleg. Dei utforska art-areal-forholdet (SAR), som er eit verktøy brukt til å estimere artsrikdom basert på storleiken på eit område. Tidlegare studiar har føreslått ei universell kurve for SAR, men denne studien fann at ei slik kurve ikkje eksisterer på grunn av variasjonar i artars utbreiingsområde, ulike krefter som påverkar SAR på ulike skalaer, og den endelege arealeffekten. Dei føreslo ein ny metode for å reskalere SAR, men konkluderte med at ei praktisk løysing for å oppskalere artsrikdom framleis er nødvendig.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-WTLGFLT5" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Artsrikdom, Art-areal-forhold, Makroøkologi, Fastlands-SAR, Romlege mønster
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-WTLGFLT5" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    Up‐scaling species richness from local to continental scales is an unsolved problem of macroecology. Macroecologists hope that proper up‐scaling can uncover the hidden rules that underlie spatial patterns in species richness, but a machinery to up‐scale species richness also has a purely practical side at the scales and for the habitats where direct observations cannot be performed. The species–area relationship (SAR) could provide a tool for up‐scaling, but no valid method has yet been put forward. Such a method would have resulted from Storch et al.'s (2012) suggestion that there is a universal curve to which each rescaled SAR collapses, if Lazarina et al. (2013) had not shown that it does not: both arguments were supported by data analyses. Here we present an analytical model for mainland SAR and argue in favour of the latter authors. We identify 1) the variation in mean species‐range size, 2) the variation in forces that drive SAR at various scales, and 3) the finite‐area effect, as the reasons for the absence of collapse. Finally, we suggest a rescaling that might fix the problem. We conclude, however, that ecologists are still far from finding a practical, robust and easy‐to‐use solution for up‐scaling species richness from SARs.
  </article>
